title: Monday, 20th November, 2017
bodyHTML:
11:01 am
BE11:02am

Morning, then.

BE11:03am

And of, course, like the rest of the internet, we're distracted by .......

BE11:03am

11:03 am
BE11:04am

King Dixit the First of the Kingdom of Dixit.

BE11:04am

https://www.facebook.com/suyashthegreat

BE11:04am

Backstory here: http://www.newswee...egypt-sudan-712818

11:05 am
BE11:05am

And good luck to ....... Actually, it's going to be King Suyash the First under the usual naming protocols, isn't it? Oh well.

BE11:05am

Do read that. It's kinda fun.

BE11:06am

Though I've a feeling we might get Milkshake Ducked on it quite soon.

11:05 am
undefined
BE11:06am

As to markets ............. it's definitely Monday.

BE11:07am

Nothing whatsoever in the weekend press to follow up, so I guess we go straight to Spire.

11:06 am
Spire Healthcare Group PLC (SPI:LSE): Last: 254.60, down 15.1 (-5.60%), High: 260.00, Low: 246.70, Volume: 2.60m
BE11:07am

Mediclinic decides, "no ta".

BE11:08am

And reminds everyone that the problem with opportunistic bids is that if the price motors out of the range of opportunism then they're likely to end.

11:08 am
Mediclinic International PLC (MDC:LSE): Last: 537.50, down 18 (-3.24%), High: 560.00, Low: 533.50, Volume: 1.81m
BE11:09am

So, Spire's dead money for at least another six months.

BE11:09am

(Ignoring the usual Code whitewashes, possibly wrongly.)

11:10 am
BE11:11am

Mediclinic saying it'll remain a "supportive shareholder" also, which if taken at face value could be seen as a negative.

BE11:11am

As it suggests Mediclinic will remain a block to any potential buyers.

BE11:12am

All this is against the backdrop of Mediclinic drifting further into multi-year low territory .......

11:12 am
BE11:13am

.... we have a bunch more downgrades post last week's numbers, which I'll come to in a second.

BE11:14am

What we can say is that the MDC revised offer of 315.5p isn't that far away from what the sellside were talking about as reasonable. As in, 320p-ish.

BE11:14am

And Jefferies, for instance, reckons standalone Spire's only worth 259p.

11:14 am
BE11:14am

Note the numbers from BMI Healthcare.

BE11:15am

Which you can extrapolate from South African-listed Netcare.

BE11:15am

Let me cut to Berenberg to take you through those.

11:15 am
BE11:16am

BMI’s PMI volumes were down 5.5% (slight worsening from its trend of -3.5% for the past 18
months, and implying c-7% for H2), while self-pay volumes were up by 9.6% for the full year (an improvement on the +6.4% in H1 and implying +12-13% in H2). The improving self-pay trend was also noted by Spire at its H1 results.

BE11:16am

NHS volume was up by 4.9% for the year (versus +8.5% in H1), driven by e-referrals (+8.4%),
partially offset by NHS contract work, down 9.3%. However, the NHS patient mix worsened,
due to the organisation’s reprioritisation of resources on A&E, primary healthcare and
cancer services, and an “escalation in NHS demand management strategies”, with a
particularly acute effect felt by BMI where triage and referral management centres have been
introduced.

BE11:16am

Overall, BMI’s inpatient volumes declined by 4.5%, with lower-revenue day cases up 2.0%.

11:16 am
BE11:16am

BMI revenue fell by 0.9%, but cost pressures and labour costs that are “not yet aligned” to the
change in patient mix led to a 14.7% fall in EBITDAR (and a 61% fall in EBITDA due to the
company’s operationally geared asset-light model). EBITDAR margin fell from 25.1% in
FY2016 to 21.6%.

BE11:17am

Berenberg was expecting Spire e-referral H2 volume growth at +2%, which suggests no further deterioration. That now looks quite heroic.

BE11:18am

We continue to believe that in the long run Spire is well positioned to benefit from structural
demand in the UK. NHS hospital infrastructure is chronically under-invested, and waiting
lists are at 10-year highs, so whether NHS funding is increased or whether patients
increasingly pay for their own care (through self-pay of medical insurance), we believe that
Spire’s well-invested portfolio will ultimately mean that it will capture market share.
However, near-term pressures create uncertainty to forecasts, and we remain on the side-
lines for now – our rating remains Hold.

11:18 am
BE11:18am

270p target, or 10x EBITDA.

BE11:19am

Meanwhile, on the Mediclinic front, Credit Suisse is typical of the downgrades ticking through.

BE11:19am

We temper the rate of EBITDA margin recovery in the UAE (cut by 2-3pt FY19-20E) due to higher start-up costs for new facilities. We also trim the Swiss EBITDA margin by 1pt FY19-20E (-3pt FY17-19E). We adopt a more cautious view on the margin impact of likely outshifting of certain inpatient procedures in 2018-19 and cost duplication associated with the Hirslanden 2020 programme, before it yields efficiency benefits long-term. Our EPS is 7-19% below consensus FY18-20E.

11:19 am
undefined
BE11:20am

Accrol mentioned!

BE11:21am

Back from suspension but refusing to autoprice. Down 66% at pixel.

11:21 am
BE11:22am

The amazing thing is that it could be worse.

BE11:22am

Because a couple of days ago, this happened:

BE11:22am

http://www.leicest...ire-sofidel-790782

11:23 am
BE11:23am

Huge fire at the Sofidel factory in Leicester.

BE11:23am

Sofidel is Accrol's main competitor.

BE11:24am

Now, you're assuming any bump to sales from a competitor's problems will be temporary.

11:25 am
BE11:25am

But you'll also remember the Accrol found itself to have been caught short, in terms of funding requirements .........

BE11:26am

.......... so while those extra orders can be classified as exceptional, the cash is still pretty useful.

BE11:26am

Anyway, just to remind @FJP, it was Zeus Capital that brought Accrol to market.

11:27 am
BE11:27am

But it's an exception in the roster of huge IPO successes from Zeus such as .........

BE11:27am

................. um .................

BE11:27am

............. Let's move on.

11:27 am
undefined
BE11:27am

Let's do some sellside, I'm bored with typing.

BE11:28am

RBC's done a lot of internet companies and not found one it wants to buy.

11:28 am
BE11:28am

We initiate on the broad European Internet sector including online retail, marketplaces and classifieds, with a constructive top-line outlook, although we have a more cautious view on margin progression. Internet stocks that can sustain superior, consistent top-line growth above market expectations will outperform long term, in our view. We therefore establish the RBC Internet Framework to identify those that are well positioned. Overlaying this with relative earnings risk and valuation drive our stock ratings: Outperform on ZPG, YNAP, ASOS, Moneysupermarket.com and Gocompare.com; and Underperform on Boohoo, Takeaway.com and Zalando (Ocado, Delivery Hero, Just Eat, Auto Trader, Scout24 and Rightmove all rated Sector Perform).

BE11:29am

(I should say, not found a new one they want to buy. Initiations are all neutral or sell I think.)

BE11:29am

We anticipate that sector revenue growth will continue to outstrip market expectations and remain the major driver of earnings growth. In a highly competitive market, we expect management teams to prioritise market share gains, reinvesting operating leverage to further innovate and enhance the proposition meaning limited margin expansion. Accordingly, our sector revenue forecasts are 3% above consensus, while EBITDA forecasts 5% below. The market generally rewards internet stocks that deliver higher-than-expected revenue growth, even if this does not result in profit upgrades. Thus, we believe stocks that can deliver superior and consistent top-line growth will outperform, particularly given the industry’s low barriers to entry and high barriers to success.

11:30 am
BE11:30am

The criteria is ..............

BE11:30am

(1) Size of Total Addressable Market (TAM); (2) Competitive Moats, which we uniquely attempt to analyse quantitatively; (3) Diversification; and (4) Attractiveness of Business Model. Product innovation is also fundamental to success. We conduct 12 consumer surveys across the sub-sectors giving us proprietary insight into potentially winning propositions and thus innovation.

BE11:31am

From that, they like (some) retail and (some) takeaway ordering. They dislike price comparison.

11:31 am
BE11:31am

Apparel and luxury are large addressable markets with low barriers to entry allowing scope for multiple internet players to take share. However, barriers to success i.e. to scale, becoming a meaningful threat to incumbents, are high and the competition for market share will remain intense. Amazon has yet to establish its credibility in fashion, but it is also a potential threat. Building defendable competitive moats is key, which we expect to come at the expense of margin upside for Zalando (Underperform) and a margin re-set for Boohoo (Underperform), as a result of rising customer acquisition costs and investments in better delivery solutions, suggesting material earnings downside risk.

BE11:31am

The online takeaway industry has faced increasing competition with global own-delivery players entering the space. The emergence of these platforms has the potential to take share of wallet away from traditional marketplaces. At the same time, barriers to success are high and multiple sizeable players operating profitably within the same market is unprecedented. Thus, we expect to observe a costly battle to gain or protect market share, thus driving higher-than-expected top-line growth but potentially weighing on profit development, in particular for Takeaway.com (Underperform).

BE11:31am

Internet classifieds: pricing power resilient, for now
A fundamental driver of the sustainability of earnings growth is pricing power. We believe long-term pricing will ultimately have to be product-led as the risks of consolidation, pressures on industry profitability or low-cost disruptors have the potential to undermine the pricing power of the incumbents over time. ZPG (Outperform) is better positioned in this regard having enlarged its product offering creating a unique and material cross-selling opportunity.

11:31 am
BE11:31am

So, that's the gist of that one.

Boohoo.Com PLC (BOO:LSE): Last: 192.00, down 7.25 (-3.64%), High: 202.50, Low: 191.50, Volume: 4.11m
ZPG PLC (ZPG:LSE): Last: 341.20, up 10.4 (+3.14%), High: 345.60, Low: 332.60, Volume: 231.08k
11:31 am
Moneysupermarket.Com Group PLC (MONY:LSE): Last: 331.10, up 0.2 (+0.06%), High: 331.70, Low: 327.10, Volume: 207.20k
ASOS PLC (ASC:LSE): Last: 5,855, up 6 (+0.10%), High: 5,942, Low: 5,788, Volume: 37.38k
Ocado Group PLC (OCDO:LSE): Last: 251.90, up 5.6 (+2.27%), High: 252.30, Low: 242.80, Volume: 2.42m
11:32 am
Auto Trader Group PLC (AUTO:LSE): Last: 320.10, down 0.2 (-0.06%), High: 321.40, Low: 317.30, Volume: 842.41k
undefined
BE11:03am

This is Markets Live, FT Alphaville's daily thing with the numbers and etc. Powering into another week with .... oh, whatever. Let's get on.

11:35 am
BE11:35am

What else, then?

BE11:36am

Bruno Monteyne, Bernstein's much-quoted grocery analyst, is turning a wee bit more cautious on Sainsbury.

J Sainsbury PLC (SBRY:LSE): Last: 225.60, down 2 (-0.88%), High: 227.60, Low: 222.40, Volume: 2.99m
11:36 am
BE11:36am

He cuts ...........

BE11:36am

2018/19 EPS by -13.4% and 2019/20 by -18.1%. The earnings cut derives entirely from a cut to the grocery-retail (ex-Argos) business

BE11:37am

That's partly on management's soft warning on H2 profitability last week

11:37 am
BE11:37am

Plus, long term guidance "shifts the goalpost" from previous "with most future margin improvement coming from Argos synergies & banking growth".

BE11:38am

Comparing pre-crisis to future recovered margin of peers suggests an industry re-set of 140 bps lower profitability. While we give credit to Sainsbury's for its remarkable resilience in the last 5 years, we should not have assumed it would be insulated from the industry reset.

BE11:38am

So, we also get some valuation stuff around Argos increasing exposure to weaker non-food consumer spending

11:38 am
BE11:39am

And also "materially higher leverage" on operating leases.

BE11:39am

Which has always been a bear case around Sainsbury. " Until markets see FCF being used to pay down debt, we think the shares will struggle to materially re-rate," says Bernstein.

BE11:40am

All of which leads them towards 250p, or 10.8x. Which might look like a bit of value from here, but here are downgrades in the pipe so don't rush in yet.

11:40 am
undefined
BE11:41am

Xaar? Xaar.

BE11:41am

FY warning.

11:41 am
BE11:42am

The Xaar investment case seems to be in a bit of a loop.

BE11:42am

We get a bunch of stuff about how Chinese houses use a lot of printed tiles and they need to invest in advance of that business turning digital.

BE11:43am

And then we get a warning that they've screwed up.

11:43 am
BE11:43am

And repeat, and repeat, and repeat.

BE11:43am

As of today we get 30% off consensus.

BE11:44am

Operating profit of £9.0-£9.5m, versus a £13.2m consensus.

11:44 am
BE11:44am

Here's Investec to take the story from here.

BE11:44am

(@Mouselet: when stuck I use Morningstar.co.uk)

BE11:45am

Xaar has been attempting to launch seven new products this year which it has never done before. We already had concerns
that this would be a stretch to execute without problems and so we are not entirely surprised to hear today that some launches
have not gone to plan. However, given the 2020 £220m revenue target, there was little room for error. The main issues are
with the 2001 and 1201 printheads as detailed below but there has also been a significant step-up in pricing competition on
the core ceramics (1003) printhead.

11:45 am
BE11:45am

At the interims in September Xaar talked about having to encourage OEMs to take the new 2001 printhead in bundled deals
with the 1003, which, to us, was a concern that the economics for this version weren’t compelling enough. Today’s news that
Xaar have had to cut the price is therefore not a total surprise. Overall, there have been fewer new digital ceramic printer
installs during the period as the ceramics industry gets closer to peak digital conversion.

BE11:46am

(@Mouselet: http://tools.morni...spx?index=FTSE_100 )

BE11:46am

(Disclaimer: Other websites are available, including ones I didn't previously work at.)

11:47 am
BE11:47am

The 1201 printhead, which is a JV with Ricoh, has shipped a significantly fewer printheads in the period than previously expected due to a production issue, we understand. We suspect this has required significant scrappage given the production process. Previously reduced guidance of £8-10m (from £15m) of 1201 revenue in FY17, has been lowered again to £5m. New production capacity is due next year to help meet customer demand.

BE11:48am

........ and Panmure, since we're here and it's a Monday.

BE11:48am

We are placing the stock under review as
we assess our forecasts and recommendation.

11:48 am
BE11:49am

There is more to Sanjay Jha's note, but it most duplicates the above so I won't bother.

undefined
BE11:50am

Blimey, it's hard work today.

11:50 am
BE11:50am

Barclays up on a Merrill upgrade, though I don't have it to hand.

Barclays PLC (BARC:LSE): Last: 187.80, up 2.8 (+1.51%), High: 187.80, Low: 185.25, Volume: 21.44m
BE11:51am

We analyse the plan to 10% ROTE by 2020. Of the gap, c 50% is low hanging fruit, 10% is plausible growth; the balance is IB. We estimate BARC has shrunk productive IB assets c 50% since '13. It is reasonable to think reinvestment will increase income. Down 17% YTD, BARC is at 0.65x 3Q17 TNAV and a relative low. Expectations rebased, 1Q18 comps easy; things can now get better.

11:52 am
BE11:52am

That's the gist of it, and Michael Helsby's the analyst.

BE11:53am

There's also some stuff around with regards the US RMBS litigation settlements

BE11:54am

The idea being that talks are back on and the direction of travel is towards an out-of-court settlement with the DOJ.

11:53 am
BE11:54am

Goldman has a 101.

BE11:54am

US RMBS precedents suggest: (i) a wide range of potential fines, from $0.8bn to $7 .5bn, with (ii) composition – between “cash” and “consumer relief” - an important factor.

BE11:54am

No meaningful provisions in place: A settlement in the above mentioned range (pro-forma for the full benefit of the deconsolidation of Barclays Africa), would reduce the group’s CET1 ratio to in between 11.5% and 13.1%, on our numbers.

11:54 am
BE11:54am

Low CET1 ratio vs. peers: UK banks have an avg CET1 ratio of 14.4% (3Q17) vs. EU IBs average 13.6% and BARC at 13.1%.

BE11:54am

Timing is a key consideration: since (i) the US CCAR includes litigation risk, and (ii) the UK ring-fenced bank will likely be established by the middle of 2018, going forward we see the potential incentive for Barclays to prioritise the resolution of major outstanding litigation items.

undefined
11:55 am
BE11:56am

Nearly there, somehow.

BE11:56am

Oh, there's Shire I guess.

Shire PLC (SHP:LSE): Last: 3,621, down 57.5 (-1.56%), High: 3,646, Low: 3,594, Volume: 747.42k
11:56 am
BE11:56am

HAVEN-3 looks pretty good.

BE11:57am

This is Roche's haemophilia thing that's going to eat all, none, or somewhere between those two points of Shire's biggest franchise by revenue.

BE11:57am

As in, ACE910 for non-inhibitor haemophilia patients

11:58 am
BE11:58am

Roche says the study met its primary endpoint, statistically significant improvement ....

BE11:59am

.... compared with no prophylaxis

BE11:59am

And more importantly, statistically significant and clinically meaningful benefit on bleed # for ACE910 vs. prophylaxis with RFVIII in an intra patient comparison.

11:59 am
BE12:00pm

Nothing interesting in safety either.

BE12:00pm

So, it's all pretty bad for Shire, which had a bit of a rally last week on the news that Roche had to include a black box warning on its pills.

BE12:01pm

Here's JP Morgan.

12:01 pm
BE12:01pm

Though strong Roche HAVEN-3 data was widely anticipated, confirmation of the strong efficacy and safety profile removes the upside optionality of any last minute hiccups for Roche, and so crystalises the competitive threat to Shire’s franchise. Arguing for Shire’s non-Haemophilia franchise being more sustainable, we note there is underlying volume growth in Haemophilia demand, Europe will likely be slow to adopt new therapies such as Hemlibra, and in the US there could be some physician financial dis-incentive to switch patients from an IV to a Subq therapy, and we still need to see the exact details of the HAVEN-3 dataset. However the counter argument is that if Roche have a statistically superior and more convenient therapeutic option (Subq and less frequent dosing), this will likely see significant patient conversion. Roche’s release this morning doesn’t give specific filing timelines, but we assume filing by ~ mid 2018, which could allow launch by early 2019. We note that in the inhibitor space, Roche was able to gain US approval within a year of the positive headline data, and approval in a second indication could be quicker. We currently model sales for Shire’s non-inhibitor Haemophilia franchise falling high single digit from 2020 onward, as a result of this competitive threat. Consensus currently models a 2% decline in 2019, which could prove conservative.

BE12:01pm

From a SOP perspective, we find the current Shire valuation has already entirely removed any value for the Haemophilia franchise, but nonetheless, in light of today’s news removing any upside Haemophilia optionality, we expect Shire to still underperform today.

BE12:02pm

And UBS .....

12:02 pm
BE12:03pm

[The Factor VIII prophylaxis to once-weekly Hemlibra result] is a strong result because bleeds are relatively infrequent (~2 per year) and there were only ~50 patients in this group, treated with Hemlibra for ~6 months. The small numbers imply a large effect for statistical significance; we estimate a 30% bleed reduction or greater.

BE12:04pm

There's also the IMpower 150 Avastin plus chemotherapy results from Roche today for first-line non-small cell lung cancer patients, the headlines on which look pretty good.

BE12:05pm

PFS benefit was seen across the entire trial population, which is good. Roche saying initial
observations positive for the co-primary end point of overall survival, which is also good.

12:06 pm
BE12:06pm

But anyway, that's a sidebar. back to Shire.

BE12:06pm

Here's Goldman.

BE12:06pm

Given Shire’s dominance in the factor VIII replacement market, HAVEN 3 study has clear implications for Shire. A positive HAVEN 3 study was widely expected given the strong results seen in HAVEN 1 and HAVEN 2 studies. While the intra-patient study indicated to Hemlibra being statistically significant compared to factor
VIII prophylaxis, we highlight that the baseline ABR (annual bleed rate) of patients in Arm D (who were on prior factor VIII prophylaxis), who had prior prophylaxis is high (greater than 9),
and is not representative of the broader Haemophilia population, without inhibitors. While we acknowledge that superiority to factor VIII prophylaxis is a headline negative for Shire, we highlight that Shire’s current share price assumes no contribution from Haemophilia franchise, in our view.

12:06 pm
undefined
BE12:07pm

Right, let's close this.

BE12:07pm

Sorry for the lack of coverage of Diploma. Results were good. That's about it really.

12:08 pm
BE12:08pm

Thanks for your comments, and for bearing with us on a newsless Monday morning when you surely have better things to do.

BE12:08pm

See you tomorrow.

BE11:35am

(@Mouselet etc: I'm sure we did some stuff on return rates a while back, but I can't remember what its conclusions was. A gold star to anyone who finds it in the archive.)
